intro: Pectis berlandieri, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its yellow composite flowers and hairy, lobed leaves. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and heat. Its leaves are often covered in fine hairs that help reduce water loss, while its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Pectis berlandieri is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in rocky or sandy habitats.
